and LF is showing signs of hubris
why is this fandom so stubborn
summary: If your theories for Winds involve Sansa Stark not being able to do anything for herself, having to listen to whatever Harry and...
body: If your theories for Winds involve Sansa Stark not being able to do anything for herself, having to listen to whatever Harry and Littlefinger say, or being unable to figure out how to get to the Wall, it might be a sign that you have a paternalistic bias toward her character. Check yourself before you wreck yourself with these bad takes.

reblog.comment: If your theories for Winds involve Sansa Stark not being able to do anything for herself, having to listen to whatever Harry and Littlefinger say, or being unable to figure out how to get to the Wall, it might be a sign that you have a paternalistic bias toward her character. Check yourself before you wreck yourself with these bad takes.

trail.content_raw: If your theories for Winds involve Sansa Stark not being able to do anything for herself, having to listen to whatever Harry and Littlefinger say, or being unable to figure out how to get to the Wall, it might be a sign that you have a paternalistic bias toward her character. Check yourself before you wreck yourself with these bad takes.
trail.content: If your theories for Winds involve Sansa Stark not being able to do anything for herself, having to listen to whatever Harry and Littlefinger say, or being unable to figure out how to get to the Wall, it might be a sign that you have a paternalistic bias toward her character. Check yourself before you wreck yourself with these bad takes.

summary: Alysanne was the queen, consort, and sister of King Jaehaerys I, the Old King, and like him she lived a long life.  Tall and...
caption:
Alysanne was the queen, consort, and sister of King Jaehaerys I, the Old King, and like him she lived a long life.  Tall and straight, unbowed by time, she had high cheekbones, clear blue eyes. […] Her relationship with King Jaehaerys was always very close. She was his most trusted counselor and his right hand, and often wore a slimmer, more feminine version of his crown at court. Beloved by the common people of Westeros, she loved them in return, and was renowned for her charities.

Sansa was the queen, consort, and cousin of King Jon I, the White Wolf, and like him she lived a long life.  Tall and straight, she had high cheekbones, clear blue eyes. […] Her relationship with King Jon was always very close. She was his most trusted counselor and his right hand, and often wore a cloak similar to his at court. Beloved by the common people of the North, she loved them in return, and was renowned for her charities.

summary: A Flame Extinguished - jashykins - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
title: A Flame Extinguished - jashykins - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: 17/30
Fandom: Game of Thrones (TV)
Rating: Mature
Warnings: Major Character Death
Relationships: Jorah Mormont/Daenerys Targaryen, Jorah Mormont/Jon Snow
Characters: Jorah Mormont, Daenerys Targaryen, Jon Snow, Jon Snow | Aegon Targaryen, Tyrion Lannister, Jaime Lannister, Sansa Stark, Samwell Tarly, Drogon (ASoIaF)
Additional Tags: Prophecy, Azor Ahai Prophecy
Summary:

On the way to Winterfell there is a devastating attack. The aftermath of the attack causes a large rift between Jorah Mormont and Jon Snow to form. Even as Jorah has to deal with his own emotions, the war against the dead won’t stop and worries about who will succeed Cersei Lannister abound.

summary: Not everybody needs to be proven right
body:
Not everybody needs to be proven right

Sansa Stark thinks no man will ever love her except for her claim. This belief does not need to be vindicated.

Brienne thinks her life is only valuable to the extent that she can protect someone else, that she’s a failure of a daughter to her daddy, and no man will ever love her as she is. Her arc would not be well-served to prove that she’s right about all of this.

Jaime blames himself for a hell of a lot of shit that was nowhere near his control, including for the murders of Elia and the kids. His guilt over failing to be in three places at once does not need to be vindicated by having him die in protecting Jon, FFS.

Tyrion has plunged to some very dark places in ADWD, and one of those dark places is thinking Jaime was never the loving brother he seemed to be. This belief does not need to be vindicated! Tyrion is allowed to have at least one still-living biological family member who loves him!

title: More Sansa = Alysanne
body:
“So there is magic beyond the Wall after all. […] Sansa would call this an enchantment, and tears would fill her eyes at the wonder of it,”
~ ACOK, Jon III

“Her first sight of the Wall from above took Alysanne’s breath away, Her Grace would later tell the king.”

“She is good at this, he thought, as he watched her tell Lord Gyles that his cough was sounding better, compliment Elinor Tyrell on her gown, and question Jalabhar Xho about wedding customs in the Summer Isles. His cousin Ser Lancel had been brought down by Ser Kevan, the first time he’d left his sickbed since the battle. He looks ghastly. Lancel’s hair had turned white and brittle, and he was thin as a stick. Without his father beside him holding him up, he would surely have collapsed. Yet when Sansa praised his valor and said how good it was to see him getting strong again, both Lancel and Ser Kevan beamed. She would have made Joffrey a good queen and a better wife if he’d had the sense to love her.”
~ ASOS, Tyrion VIII

Delighted by the girl’s daring, Alysanne summoned her own sworn shield, Jonquil Darke, and the wildling and the Scarlet Shadow dueled spear against sword whilst the northmen roared in approval. […]  Even a lord as stern and flinty as Alaric Stark found himself helpless before Queen Alysanne’s stubborn charm. […]  The longer the queen stayed, the more Lord Alaric warmed to her, and in time Alysanne came to realize that not everything that was said of him was true. […]  The men of the Night’s Watch were as thunderstruck by the queen’s dragon as the people of White Harbor had been…”

Good Queen Alysansa confirmed.

blog.name: mediiciis
blog.title: H I A T U S.

tags: sorry this took me so long
i know you sent me this last night and have probably found the info you were looking for elsewhere
but i actually enjoyed getting my thoughts on this down so 🤷🏼‍♀️
if you’re still around...i hope this helped 😊
summary: i feel stupid... can you please explain how the alysane->sansa parallels have anything to do with jonsa? everything i see is all...
question: i feel stupid... can you please explain how the alysane->sansa parallels have anything to do with jonsa? everything i see is all about sansa and i don't see how it connects to her relationship with jon. i'm not trying to argue or troll you i swear, i really am just a dumbass who wants to understand, but doesn't.
answer:
Well it’s because of what the implications of these parallels are. They’re not just isolated comparisons, they signpost and foreshadow certain things about the future of Sansa’s arc. They’re part of a bigger picture - a picture I believe (as do many others, including book-reading non-shippers) includes Jonsa as one of the narrative strands and threads that will ultimately make up the fabric of Sansa’s endgame.

So, put simply: if GRRM is drawing comparisons between Sansa and Alysanne in things such as temperament, personality, life experiences etc. then he obviously wants us to connect the two. And one implication of this connection is that the other things about Alysanne’s life that have yet to align with Sansa may be a hint for where she’s headed and clue us in as to where her narrative is going. And that includes Alysanne’s romantic arc - which matches up in many ways to Sansa’s dynamic with Jon.

For example, besides all the blatant Sansa/Alysanne similarities inc. their personalities, affinity for the small folk, infamous beauty, charming ‘Queenly’ demeanour, both of them having 5 siblings, both of their families being hostages and captives during wartime, both of them watching their family die during conflict, and the way they both wore down even the most stubborn of Northern Lords due to sheer charm and courtesy (it’s a ladies armour, after all) - also lmao at people really thinking she parallel’s D*ny because dRaGoNs - I think GRRM is just a tad more nuanced than that, don’t you? Alysanne is nothing like D*ny in any way other than name and dragon 😂 a thematic parallel is usually built on a lot more than that) - it’s worth noting that Alysanne was also a Queen who ruled strongly beside her King (Jaehaerys) as Sansa has been doing in the North with Jon, and especially in his absence (an important component of the excerpt), and who, rather quite crucially in regards to the question of Jonsa, ended up marrying her oldest surviving brother - as Jon is now to Sansa, at least ostensibly - although he’s technically her cousin, which is an important and interesting distinction, in that it separates this dynamic from the questionable Targaryen practices of blood purity and incest between first-degree relatives - the ugly blemish on the face of Jaehaerys and Alysanne’s otherwise untarnished rule (it was the very practice of incestous inter-sibling marriage which provoked the Faith uprising that ultimately led to war, rebellion and the deaths of many members of their family, after all) - Jon and Sansa are arguably Jaehaerys and Alysanne with this one ‘kink’ smoothed out by the intervention of Jon’s true parentage.

When you combine all of this with the fact that Jon himself has quite a few parallels to Jaehaerys (Alysanne’s brother, husband and King - 2/3 there with Jonsa)..it starts to add up.

If you wanna get really tinfoil-y you could even be all…Jon is a Targaryen with a J name (Jaehaerys?) and both of Sansa’s names (ALaYne and SANsa) make up the name ALYSANNE. (If you think this argument is too flimsy just remember that GRRM got Hodor’s name from ‘hold the door.’ It’s extremely probable that he constructed both Sansa’s name and her alias as derivatives of ‘Alysanne’.)

So yes, while the Alysanne comparisons are focused strictly on Sansa, it would be short-sighted to not consider what the implications of these parallels could be. And, imo, it’s a positive opening for Jonsa if I ever saw one.

Thanks for the ask!

If you wanna read some more about the Sansa/Alysanne parallels (including those which hint heavily at Jonsa through the Jaehaerys&Alysanne/Jon&Sansa mirroring), and the Sansa/Eleanor of Aquitaine comparisons - who GRRM has said he modelled Alysanne on - which seem to bring the Alysanne/Sansa link full circle, THIS THREAD on Twitter is a good place to start.

ALL HAIL KING JONHAERYS AND GOOD QUEEN ALYSANSA!! 😉

reblog.comment:
Well it’s because of what the implications of these parallels are. They’re not just isolated comparisons, they signpost and foreshadow certain things about the future of Sansa’s arc. They’re part of a bigger picture - a picture I believe (as do many others, including book-reading non-shippers) includes Jonsa as one of the narrative strands and threads that will ultimately make up the fabric of Sansa’s endgame.

So, put simply: if GRRM is drawing comparisons between Sansa and Alysanne in things such as temperament, personality, life experiences etc. then he obviously wants us to connect the two. And one implication of this connection is that the other things about Alysanne’s life that have yet to align with Sansa may be a hint for where she’s headed and clue us in as to where her narrative is going. And that includes Alysanne’s romantic arc - which matches up in many ways to Sansa’s dynamic with Jon.

For example, besides all the blatant Sansa/Alysanne similarities inc. their personalities, affinity for the small folk, infamous beauty, charming ‘Queenly’ demeanour, both of them having 5 siblings, both of their families being hostages and captives during wartime, both of them watching their family die during conflict, and the way they both wore down even the most stubborn of Northern Lords due to sheer charm and courtesy (it’s a ladies armour, after all) - also lmao at people really thinking she parallel’s D*ny because dRaGoNs - I think GRRM is just a tad more nuanced than that, don’t you? Alysanne is nothing like D*ny in any way other than name and dragon 😂 a thematic parallel is usually built on a lot more than that) - it’s worth noting that Alysanne was also a Queen who ruled strongly beside her King (Jaehaerys) as Sansa has been doing in the North with Jon, and especially in his absence (an important component of the excerpt), and who, rather quite crucially in regards to the question of Jonsa, ended up marrying her oldest surviving brother - as Jon is now to Sansa, at least ostensibly - although he’s technically her cousin, which is an important and interesting distinction, in that it separates this dynamic from the questionable Targaryen practices of blood purity and incest between first-degree relatives - the ugly blemish on the face of Jaehaerys and Alysanne’s otherwise untarnished rule (it was the very practice of incestous inter-sibling marriage which provoked the Faith uprising that ultimately led to war, rebellion and the deaths of many members of their family, after all) - Jon and Sansa are arguably Jaehaerys and Alysanne with this one ‘kink’ smoothed out by the intervention of Jon’s true parentage.

When you combine all of this with the fact that Jon himself has quite a few parallels to Jaehaerys (Alysanne’s brother, husband and King - 2/3 there with Jonsa)..it starts to add up.

If you wanna get really tinfoil-y you could even be all…Jon is a Targaryen with a J name (Jaehaerys?) and both of Sansa’s names (ALaYne and SANsa) make up the name ALYSANNE. (If you think this argument is too flimsy just remember that GRRM got Hodor’s name from ‘hold the door.’ It’s extremely probable that he constructed both Sansa’s name and her alias as derivatives of ‘Alysanne’.)

So yes, while the Alysanne comparisons are focused strictly on Sansa, it would be short-sighted to not consider what the implications of these parallels could be. And, imo, it’s a positive opening for Jonsa if I ever saw one.

ALL HAIL KING JONHAERYS AND GOOD QUEEN ALYSANSA!! 😉

blog.description: Fantasy aficionado since I read Tolkien in my teenage years. I still love Tolkien but I am also into other works. I love ASOIAF (books) and GoT (Show). I also like Brandon Sanderson, Lois McMaster Bujold, in short in my free time it's fantasy...Header by courtesy of ragekitn!

tags: Will Jaime swear himself to Sansa?
summary: Hi do you think Jamie will bend the knee to Sansa?
question: Hi do you think Jamie will bend the knee to Sansa?
answer:
Dear nonny,

“Sansa Stark is my last chance for honor.“ (ASOS, Jaime IX)

I think Jaime bending knee to Sansa would tie up several threads. Jaime’s thread about becoming a true knight again, Sansa’s thread about inspiring knights, Jaime’s possible arc of becoming the Hand (my new favourite theory), two slow learners together, a possible Stark-Lannister reconciliation that would benefit the realm and bring peace, Jaime finding a worthy queen to serve, Jaime and Brienne as protectors of Catelyn’s daughter, possible Braime with lots of very tall children, Catelyn saving Jaime’s life having a good result (which would tie in with the positive effect of saving individual lives which is a Stark theme)….

Honestly, I think I would cry. I want this so much, that my brain gets mushed… And I think we have a chance way above zero to see that.

Thanks for the ask!
